Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 4f0d1de67e310404c93c0b4266f936850890b036
is this header utilized here ..?
Nope, not anymore. Removed.
same as above .
Null check is required for this before memcpy..?
Ack. See above
These buffers are guaranteed to exist and not NULL checked in any other the handlers in this project or the parent (e.g. https://github.com/rfrandse/phosphor-host-ipmid/blob/master/oemrouter.cpp#L92)
same as line number 55.
Ack
If C header ..? You can put under extern "C" { }

It is, but none of the other header files in this project use extern C for it.

Is this something new we're migrating to moving forward? It seems it would be better to have a single change to add it to all headers simultaneously.
I am not sure if we want to have four different commands here or have subcommands under `SysAccelOob`
Either way is fine with me, but the original discussion was to add them here.
I don't know if we want to use boost flat_map here. It might be too heavy for the handlers.

The only example of handling GetManagedObjects return value ("a{oa{sa{sv}}}") used it, so I copied that.

`vector<pair<...>>` should suffice here.

Use `using` instead?

```
using AnyType = std::variant<std::string, uint8_t, uint32_t, uint64_t>;
```
Done
no need for this wrapper?
This is to provide a hook to inject the mock dbus during testing. See handler_impl.hpp:66-67
ack.
bus.call_noreply
Done

rm?

Also you should all the Google Licence here. Checkout the other cpp for a copy of it.
Done

for these structs? do you not need in the unit tests to confirm the size of the response?

How some this is different from what the test uses?

The unit test does verify the size, e.g. on line 58: ```ASSERT_EQ(reply_buff.size(), sizeof(Reply));```

> How some this is different from what the test uses?

The test includes the entire Reply struct specific to that case. For calls without variable size fields (e.g. DeviceCount, as opposed to Read or Write) this isn't very interesting but it makes the test extremely easy to read and follows a common format with the other, more complicated test cases.
where did this one come from?

The trailing NULL for the c-string. This isn't strictly necessary, but it makes using these replies easier.

The documented API says that trailing NULL terminators are optional for input arguments, and will be included in generated return values.
rm?

No. These are actually part of the expected struct, but because name is variable length I need to break it into 2 pieces. These fields get handled by the ReadNameHeader method and this represents what's left of the Request.

Added some comments to clarify
no need
Done.
prefer `static_cast<uint64_t>`
Done
just `ACCEL_OOB_ROOT + name`? same with the others
Unfortunately, there isn't an operator+(string_view, string_view).
if we put the struct in the header, then we don't have to maintain two of these.
That was how I originally had it, but it doesn't work for the commands with variable-sized structs (containing the name). For consistency, I kept the fixed-size methods the same.
nit: This doesn't seem to be a complete sentence.
Done
question: Here and at the write command, would it make sense to explicitly denote endianness?
Done.
nit: should we take this out?
Done

nit: I guess the caveat here is that the minimum buffer (if returned at the first conditional) may not be enough to hold the name as well.

It seems we use it for checking against 0 so I don't think the nit matters, just pointing out that the comment can look misleading.
Fixed by removing the first conditional. Having the actual size returned is helpful if using dynamic allocation, and that first early exit doesn't add much value anyway.
nit : if C header you can put under extern "C" { }

We don't do this in any of the other files in this repo.

Is this a new thing we're moving towards?
Or, is it better to maintain consistency?
Done
minor nit: as mentioned in the header, perhaps change this to index for consistency / readability
Done
minor nit: would prefer for this to follow the interface's param name of "index"
Done
nit : if C header ,can be put under extern "C" { }
Ack. See comment in google_accel_oob.hpp

really minor nit: Technically should be camel case I imagine (following OpenBMC standard to the letter) but I also think this is clearer denoting the expected test status. I think it's ok to leave it as is.
Ack
nit: I think you meant Device here probably (and below)
Done

nit: Since you don't seem to use the returned value and you have everything in sequence within this anyway, I wonder if it's easier if you just declare ::testing::InSequence s; at the top of this helper function, then you don't have to return (can be void return) and you don't need the "InSequence(s)" at each EXPECT_CALL
Done + for ExpectRead and ExpectWrite as well
Same here as above
Done
Same here as above
Done

I can't add the normal +2 group (perhaps it doesn't exist for google-ipmi-sys repo?)

Can someone do a +2 approval review?

The +2 group is for our internal downstream repo. 

I believe we have the OWNER files set up so that the maintainers are added automatically in this review.
venture@ or wak@, looking for a +2 approval
Can we make this simpler by declaring the header part of the request separately, and then subtracting that size out from MAX_IPMI_BUFFER?
That actually gets very messy. Since this is effectively the union of all the structs that include name, we'd need to create a bunch of intermediate size sums and take a max of them all.
I think all of the subcommand parsing logic is vestigal since the rewrite and needs to be removed here. AFAIR the data span doesn't contain it.
Done

nit: I can try to find the advice on this internally but where possible, it's encouraged to memcpy data over, so you'd create a Reply on the stack, set the value there, and then memcpy it into the vector.

Post-refactoring, I believe this is a non-issue: the return value contains the reply buffer (as a parameterized type, std::vector in this case) so the copy or move gets done in the ::ipmi::responseSuccess ctor.

In all of these new methods, replyBuf is already a local vector (e.g. line 69, above)

I don't think we want to copy anything but the subcommand back to conform with the typical conventions in the repo. All responses start with the oem + cmd bytes, but then the rest of the request is not sent back.

This is actually an intentional addition. In the past, we've had cases were transactions get lost (either the request or reply get dropped, corrupted, or delayed). When this happens, the host doesn't know until the next command completes. By echoing the command back, the host can very easily and unambiguously determine which transaction a reply belongs to.

The read & write commands include an additional "token" field so that repeated operations (e.g. multiple writes to the same register) can still be differentiated as well.

If the number of bytes on the wire is a concern, just having the token field should be sufficient.
Don't you only use IPMI over net? Is there not already a transaction system at a higher level? It seems like a problem that we need to implement it here, but none of the other IPMI commands have it.

No IPMI over LPC still exists too.

> It seems like a problem that we need to implement it here, but none of the other IPMI commands have it.

That's correct, and it's caused a lot of headaches in the past. Given that reads and writes are generally going to be batched in larger groups than most IPMI commands, those headaches are going be to significantly worse without some mitigation.
nit: We shouldn't need to declare everything in C api's extern for ABI compat, it should be built-in to the header if needed.
Done. This was added in response to a previous review comment, but seemed out of place given that it's not used anywhere else in the repo.
nit: why use string_view for one versus char* for all? (I see it's the only one you use for .length().  Perhaps then just use string_view for all?

All of the others are passed as arguments that need to be char*, which makes string_view a bad idea: go/totw/1#a-few-additional-notes

With string_view literals it's probably safe to assume they will be null terminated, but then it still adds a bunch of extra .data() accessors every time we use it.
superfluous semicolon here and below
Done
Is the api.h header a C header?  I don't recall it being one or compiled into a C library.  If the sd-bus.h that it then includes is what you're considering, please make the fix there for all.
It is, but we don't wrap it in extern C anywhere else it's used. This was added in response to a previous review comment, but seemed out of place to me.
endianness? This should probably use the boost wrapper `boost::endian::little_uint64_t`

I intentionally didn't put any endian definition here because I don't want to introduce any swapping. As it stands, all of the interfaces will handle things as byte arrays (endian independent) and we just treat the addresses as opaque values so the endianess doesn't matter.

By not doing any swapping, we can be sure that the order of bytes provided in the IPMI command will be the same order that will go out to the ASIC.
I guess we can update the year of the copyright now.
Done for all files in this patchset
do we need to check to make sure that the string is lone enough?
It always should because of the service we're using, but added a full prefix check (instead of just length) for defense in depth.

Patchset 19 addresses Willy's comments.

Patchset 20 adds a associated documentation for the new IpmiException, which I missed in 19.

PTAL
